channel.title: Programming and framework suggestions
channel.description:
If people, will not name those in mind already, decide to perpetuously post comments starting an argument on others decisions I'd prefer if a moderator closes this sooner than to let it stir up. Other than that, I would appreciate your suggestions and I'd like to see personal preferences on which web application framework and languages people prefer.
If your personal WebApplication preference isn't added already, like .Net or anything else, I will add it if you just comment. These are just the few I numbered my viewpoint down to.
Thanks in advance :D ;)
(Could've/Should've posted in the Web Development section, I guess. Hope it doesn't affend many.)

item.title: Programming and framework suggestions
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I can’t take PHP seriously because it’s developed by a team that don’t think the fact (“9223372036854775807” == “9223372036854775808”) == true is a bug.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming and framework suggestions
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

PHP looks like shit, yes. But it has served its purpose quite well over the years for me. I believe that’s because I created my own framework, which I find pretty good. Not to mention the Eclipse plugin support, which also helped me quite a bit.

On the other hand, I’ve never been a fan of ASP, ASP.NET or JSP. Although, I believe JavaFX may become a great alternative in the future.

Read full topic

OP probably thinks .NET layered on an internet protocol.
[/quote]

I meant it literal. As in anything remotely related to networking. I typoed first time.

item.title: Programming and framework suggestions
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

The one thing PHP does have in its favour is market share. There probably isn’t a hosting company in the world that doesn’t offer PHP (with the exception of those that have specifically targeted the other comparably niche platforms).

But as a language it’s tedious in my experience. I prefer strongly typed languages and those which aren’t so easy to introduce typographic errors into. In PHP you can unknowingly introduce new variables. If you have an IDE that picks it up then that’s nice, but if not you could be scratching your head for a while wondering why something’s wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Programming and framework suggestions
item.dc:creator: @Adobe Adobe
item.description:
@Adobe wrote:

Figured I already knew C# Syntax from a while back so what could ASP.Net hurt? I Did install PHP, Apache, etc but after the comments I doubt it’s worth getting into. Scanning ASP it seems like its short and easy, going to give node.js a try. All else fails, There is always RoR to try.
The reasoning behind PHP, was because around my location on Monster, nearly all companies are looking for PHP or .Net developers. There was one for RoR, but only one. Language choosing does depend on enjoyment, I do support this statement. I personally enjoy programming in general, so the determining factor of which language is what is in demand around me. I will certainly try each of the suggested though.

Read full topic
